document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Neotropical genus Macreupelmus Ashmead (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Eupelmidae)

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 15 – 23. Macreupelmus auranticrus n. sp. 15 – 18, holotype: 15, lateral habitus; 16, frons; 17, fore wing costal cell; 18, medial part of fore wing. 19, propodeal plical region (2016 - 7). 20, face (holotype). 21 – 23, 2016 - 7: 21, gena and antennae [insert: arrows point to apical margin of pedicel and ventral margin of scape]; 22, middle leg, tibial apex and base of tarsus; 23, Gt 6, posterolateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. From the Latin words aurantium (orange) and crus (leg) in reference to the partly orangish legs of females.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 15–23 .
Macreupelmus auranticrus
n. sp. 15–18 , holotype: 15 , lateral habitus; 16 , frons; 17 , fore wing costal cell; 18 , medial part of fore wing. 19 , propodeal plical region (2016-7). 20 , face (holotype). 21–23 , 2016-7: 21 , gena and antennae [insert: arrows point to apical margin of pedicel and ventral margin of scape]; 22 , middle leg, tibial apex and base of tarsus; 23 , Gt6, posterolateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Macreupelmus auranticrus
forms a species complex along with
M. laticlavius
and
M. brasiliensis
. Females of the three are similar to those of
M. granulosus
in lacking the hyaline band with white setae between the basal cell and disc ( Figs 18 , 43–45 , 89 , 99 ) and in having a medially long propodeal plical region ( Figs 19 , 41 , 94 ), but differ from the former in having Gt6 reticulate ( Figs 23 , 51 , 105 ) rather than granular ( Fig. 95 ) and the mesotibial apical pegs in a patch of two or more rows ( Figs 22 , 48 , 100 ) rather than a single row. The former feature likely is symplesiomorphic within
Macreupelmus
, but the latter feature is more likely synapomorphic. The two known females of
M. auranticrus
are very similar to those of
M. brasiliensis
except for their paler legs ( cf. Figs 15 , 34 ) and somewhat more extensively pale scapes ( cf. Figs 21 , 40 ). It is possible that these differences represent only regional color forms of a single species, but the two
M. auranticrus
females differ also from typical
M. brasiliensis
females in their somewhat narrower scape such that when the pedicel and scape are at a right angle to each other the pedicel extends obviously beyond the ventral margin of the scape ( Fig. 21 , insert).
